text: Colleague David Spunt rpts AG Barr leaves Doj. Barr has been reviewing the Mueller rpt. Memo on rpt won’t be sent to CapHill for mbrs to review until Sunday at earliest, perhaps by midday

text:
Source familiar w/Dem Conf call: Pelosi told Dems she would oppose 
just a classified briefing of the Gang of 8 or any other classified configurations. She wants an unclassified briefing so mbrs can speak about it publicly

text: Chairs Nadler, Cummings, Neal, Engel, Waters and Schiff all spoke on conf call. They are pushing for release of documents so Congress can probe administration.
author: ChadPergram

text: Pelosi to Hse Dems on conf call: We are in the mode wanting to know the truth, wanting the facts so that our Chairpersons and Members of the Committees can take a look into this going forward.
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) On Dem conf call. Dems discussed that Mueller may have not been willing or had evidence to prosecute others, based on his mandate. But Hse Dems told their mbrs they can go further if necessary. Fox is told impeachment was not mentioned on the call.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) On Hse Dem conf call: Several sources downplayed idea that call was effort to placate Dems who want to go to the mat w/admin & maybe push impeachment. Other Dem sources suggested that was INDEED the underlying purpose of the conf call
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) On Hse Dem conf call: House Democrats wanted to remind their rank and file members that the House committees have a broader purview and can go further than Mueller, if necessary.
author: ChadPergram

text: 1) On Hse Dem Caucus conf call: Fox is told that part of the purpose was to assert that just because Mueller is done, the Hse Dems were telling its mbrs they still have work to do & have broader jurisdiction than Mueller. Hence the 6 cmtes chairs on the call.
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse Ds now holding caucus-wide conf call on Mueller rpt. Pelosi opposes impeachment. But many Ds want to forge ahead. Those tensions are heightened w/release of tbe rpt. Pelosi has key cmte chairs on the call to discuss their probes..& to show Dems they are conducting probes
author: ChadPergram

text: Pelosi to Hse Dems: Congress requires the full report and the underlying documents so that the Committees can proceed with their independent work, including oversight and legislating to address any issues the Mueller report may raise.
author: ChadPergram

text: Pelosi to Hse Dems: Even if DOJ chooses not to prosecute additional individuals, the underlying findings must be provided to Congress and the American people.  The Attorney General’s offer to provide the Committees with a summary of the report’s conclusions is insufficient.
author: ChadPergram

text:
Pelosi to Hse Dems:
We are insisting that any briefings to any Committees be unclassified so that Members can speak freely about every aspect of the report and not be confined to what DOJ chooses to release publicly.
author: ChadPergram

text: Pelosi to Hse Dems: Today, we are having an emergency Caucus conference call at 3:00 p.m. E.T. to discuss the transmittal of the Mueller  Rpt..While we do not know the substance..we will have the relevant Committees..on the call today to update Members on where we go from here.

I am concerned executive privilege could be asserted broadly here

text: On calls for Barr/Mueller to appear before Congress...Whitewater/Monica Lewinsky Independent Counsel Ken Starr publicly testified before the House Judiciary Committee on November 19, 1998 after releasing his report earlier that summer

text:
Coons advocates a public hearing with Attorney General William Barr and Special Counsel Robert Mueller:
It would put them on the record publicly...There are going to be a lot of folks with lingering doubts and questions

text:
Coons on Mueller report:
I think there is more for us here to unpack in Congress

text:
Coons on what people should interpret about no additional indictments:
It’s possible that Mueller concluded there would be no indictment of the President...He may have concluded there was no evidence..or there was nothing there strong enough to challenge that policy

text:
Coons:
Until we’ve got that outcome, none of us really knows what Robert Mueller found or didn’t find

text:
Coons on conjecture now about what’s in the report:
We should be thoughtful and cautious..we shouldn’t get ahead of oursleves

Coons:
I’m relieved the Special Counsel Mueller was able to complete his investigation

text: 6) McConnell Green New Deal gambit is all aimed at getting Democratic senators running for President on the record about the proposal
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) McConnell is engineering votes tied to the Green New Deal to try to get Dems on the record either for or against the plan. If Dems vote yes, GOPers would portray them as radicals. If they vote no, GOPers would say Green New Deal is so unpopular Dems won't even back it
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) So, needing 60 yeas just to start debate on the Green New Deal, it’s unclear if McConnell can be successful in that gambit. Regardless, that procedural vote would be two steps away from a final vote on the measure.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) The procedural vote in relation to the Green New Deal would not be on the bill..or even to finish debate on the bill. This would be a procedural vote..just to finish debate on whether or the Senate should PROCEED to the bill.
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) After the vote to reject the national emergency, McConnell filed cloture on the MOTION TO PROCEED to the measure. Filing cloture is an effort to end a filibuster. 60 yeas are required.
author: ChadPergram

text: The last unsuccessful attempt to override a veto came in February, 2016. President Obama vetoed a Republican effort to repeal Obamacare. The House voted 241-186, well short of the 285 yeas needed to override.
author: ChadPergram

text: Only 111 successful veto overrides in US history
author: ChadPergram

text: Presidents have only vetoed 2,500 pieces of legislation in the history of the republic. But the Founders wanted to give Congress one last chance to go over the head of the executive. That’s a veto override. Alexander Hamilton invented the idea of an override in Federalist 73.
author: ChadPergram

text: Veto is Latin for “I forbid.” But you won’t find the word “veto” itself anywhere in the Constitution. Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution says if the President likes a bill, he can sign it. If he doesn’t, he can veto it and return the legislation to Capitol Hill.
author: ChadPergram

text: House/Senate are now aligned on ending national emergency. The measure now goes to President Trump. He is expected to use his veto for the first time. A two-thirds vote is needed by both bodies to override. Hse came up 40 votes shy of votes to override. Senate was 8 votes shy

text:
10) The failed veto override attempt on the bill to repeal Obamacare is the last unsuccessful veto override effort. 

The measure would not go to the Senate, even if Hse does not try to override Mr. Trump on the border emergency. That’s because the House originated the measure.
author: ChadPergram

text: 9) Pelosi may elect to let the “process play out” here too. But a vote to override by vulnerable Democrats is a tougher vote to take…compared to a vote to repeal Obamacare..taken by GOPers in 2016.
author: ChadPergram

text: 8) Republicans failed to override Obama on his veto of the bill to repeal Obamacare. Spkr Ryan lacked the votes…but said at the time he would let “the process play out.”
author: ChadPergram

text: 7) Voting to override President Obama’s veto of a bill to repeal Obamacare was an easier vote to cast for House Republicans in February, 2016. Republicans had campaigned since 2009 that they would repeal Obamacare. So voting to override the President was a good vote for GOPers
author: ChadPergram

text: 6) Republicans would attempt to weaponize a vote to override the President’s veto against the vulnerable Democrats. So, it’s possible Pelosi could opt out of that vote because it would be a challenging one for her members.
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) Pelosi MAY decide that a vote to override the President’s sole veto may not be a good vote to cast by many of her moderate to conservative freshman Democrats. They represent battleground districts where the President is popular.
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) A successful veto override needs a 2/3 vote by both the House and Senate. Presidents have vetoed 2,500 bills in U.S. history. Congress has only overridden a President 111 times.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) Vetoed nat'l emergency pkg would go back to Hse since bill origniated there. The House came up 40 votes shy of the threshold needed to override when it okayed bill to terminate the national emergency. So, the House really has no chance to successfully execute a veto override.
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) The Senate will likely vote to terminate the national emergency today. Then the House and Senate are aligned. The measure would go to the White House. President Trump has threatened a veto. The measure would then return to Capitol Hill.
author: ChadPergram

text: 1) House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) would not commit to holding a vote to override President Trump if he vetoes a measure to overturn his national emergency when asked by Fox this morning.
author: ChadPergram

text: Trump now speaking at the Capitol speaking to the Friends of Ireland Lunch. Asks Pelosi how McCarthy is doing as Minority Leader.

text: Every year the Irish Taoiseach or Prime Minister comes to the Capitol for a special luncheon with the President and lawmakers. Taoiseach is pronounced TEE-shock

text: Trump headed to the Capitol for the Friends of Ireland Lunch with Speaker Pelosi & Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar

text: GOP IN Sen Young on death of fmr Sen Dem IN Sen Birch Bayh: "Birch Bayh is a modern-day founding father. He used his tenure in the Senate to push for substantive and substantial change, including two constitutional amendments and the passage of Title IX."
author: ChadPergram

text: Fmr Sen. Birch Bayh (D-IN) dies at 91. Served three terms from 1963-1981. Is the father of former Sen. Evan Bayh (D-IN). The elder Bayh authored Title IX, (a section of the Higher Education Act in the early 1970s) which barred discrimination against women in sports and education.
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate votes to end U.S. involvement in Yemen. This was the latest in a series of rebuffs to the President over foreign policy, led by an insurgent group of Republican senators. The vote was 54-46. Seven GOP senators voted in favor of the resolution.

text: Dem TX Rep Al Green tried to bring impeachment articles to flr last yr. He may so again. Hse moved to table or kill consideration of those articles. So, there was no direct vote on the impeachment articles. The vote was on the motion to table, & kill Green’s impeachment gambit

text: On Pelosi rejecting impeachment push. There aren’t the votes to impeach in the House right now. And there certainly aren’t the votes in the Senate to convict and remove the President

text: On Pelosi rejecting impeachment push. Democrats won the House, not because they elected liberals in urban, left-wing Democrats. They elected moderate Democrats in swing districts and the suburbs. Pelosi’s decision also protects those members, too.

text:
Multiple Hse Cmtes now probing Trump. Dems say the probes are worthwhile. But they also seevenalso a panacea to hold off those who want to impeach the President.

text: 8) The last successful veto override came in Sept '16. Obama vetoed the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act. The measure allowed families of 9/11 victims to sue those responsible or the attacks, including Saudi Arabia.
author: ChadPergram

text: 7) The last unsuccessful attempt to override a veto came in Jan '16. Obama vetoed a GOP effort to repeal Obamacare. The House voted 241-186, well short of the 285 yeas needed to override. The maneuver never went to the Senate since the override maneuver failed in the House.
author: ChadPergram

text: 6) Presidents have only vetoed 2,500 pieces of legislation in the history of the republic. But the Founders wanted to give Congress one last chance to go over the head of the executive. That’s a veto override. Only 111 successful veto overrides in US history. About 4 percent
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) Congress never overrode a single veto until 1845. President John Tyler holds the ignominious distinction of becoming the 1st President to experience a veto override. Tyler vetoed a spending bill to pay for what’s now the Coast Guard. Hse/Senate objected, overriding Tyler.
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) President Obama vetoed his first piece of legislation after only 11 months on the job. President George W. Bush never vetoed a bill until he was in office for five-and-a-half years. President Bill Clinton didn’t use a veto until two-and-a-half years into his presidency.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) Alexander Hamilton engineered the idea of a Presidential veto in Federalist Paper number 73. Hamilton argued in favor of the veto, saying the president may periodically need to hold Congress in check.
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) Veto is Latin for “I forbid.” But you won’t find the word “veto” itself anywhere in the Constitution. Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution says if the President likes a bill, he can sign it. If he doesn’t, he can veto it and return the legislation to Capitol Hill.
author: ChadPergram

text: 12) In 2011, Russia moved to Daylight Saving Time year-round. Portions of British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Quebec and Nunavut in Canada remain on Standard Time.
author: ChadPergram

text: 11)  Some recent studies indicated that saving energy in the evening is now eviscerated by people flipping on the lights, air conditioning, furnaces and coffee machines earlier in the morning. A 2010 Utah State study asserted that the time changes costs $1.7 billion a year.
author: ChadPergram

text: 10) Under the law, the new calendar shifted the beginning DST from what had been early April to early March. On the back end, Daylight Saving Time would no longer cease in October but early November.
author: ChadPergram

text: 9) Between 2003 and 2005, Congress wrestled with a massive, comprehensive piece of energy legislation. Buried in the legislation was provision to extend the period of Daylight Saving Time.
author: ChadPergram

text: 8) Congress updated the law again in 1986. Daylight Saving Time would start on the first Sunday in April and clocks would return to Standard Time on the final Sunday in October. But Congress installed a “sunset” (ahem) on this policy for 2006.
author: ChadPergram

text: 7) The 1973 OPEC oil embargo forced Congress to implement year-round Daylight Saving Time for 2 yrs to decrease fuel consumption. Advocates for the “longer” days argued that time shifting cut down on crime, traffic accidents. The fuel savings proved negligible.
author: ChadPergram

text: 6) Arizona and Michigan immediately opted out. But Congress updated the law six years later to allow states which were federally split by time zones to choose their own time, such as Indiana.
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) Congress approved the Uniform Time Act of 1966. It mandated that people would advance their clocks by an hour at 2 am on the last Sunday in April. Initially, states could only request a waiver from the federal government from Daylight Saving Time
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) By executive order FDR imposed year-round “War Time,” moving the clocks ahead for an hour. After World War II ended in 1945, most eastern and northern instituted Daylight Saving Time in the warmer months.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) The 1918 time measure proved to be unpopular and Congress prepared another piece of legislation to end Daylight Saving Time. President Woodrow Wilson subsequently vetoed the bill. But both houses of Congress executed a rare, successful override.
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) Sometimes referred to as the Calder Act, the law established the four continental time zones of the United States. Spurred by World War I and efforts to save fuel, Congress initiated “summer” Daylight Saving Time in late March 1918.
author: ChadPergram

text: 1) If you feel cheated out of an extra hour of sleep tonight thanks to Daylight Saving Time, blame Congress & Ben Franklin. In 1784, Franklin advocated “springing ahead” in spring & “falling back” to save candles. Congress approved the Standard Time Act in 1918
author: ChadPergram

text: 8) 116th Congress is only 2months old. The Senate has no failed cloture votes on a nomination available for a revote at this stage. A revote on a failed cloture vote is non-debatable. That's the option to try to establish a new precedent & curb post-cloture time on some nominees
author: ChadPergram

text: 7) If following the path of Nuclear Options I & II, Parliamentarian will rule against that assertion on flr. Senators can then try to override the ruling The Senate would then vote on “Shall the decision of the Chair stand as the judgment of the Senate?”
author: ChadPergram

text: 6) Nuclear Option is where Senate is backed into a parliamentary cul-de-sac where nothing else is debatable. Senate needs a failed cloture vote on a nominee. GOP can make pt of order that it should only have to burn 2 hrs of debate rather than 30, post-cloture
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) “The Nuclear Option” is a parliamentary maneuver to establish new Senate PRECEDENT. Not a rules change. Senate often relies on precedent. It takes 67 votes to end a filibuster on a rules change. Only a simple majority to establish a new precedent.
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) If GOPers wish to abbreviate the “post-cloture” time, they need to have at least a simple majority of senators who wish to establish a new precedent. Plus, they likely have to follow the playbook used for Nuclear Option I & 2 to lower the bar for cloture for all nominees
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) Senate permits up to 30 hours of debate once senators vote to end debate on any nominee. GOP proposal would lower bar to 2 hrs after Senate votes to end debate before nomination. GOP criticizes Dems forcing Senate to burn 30 hrs despite little opposition to some nominees.
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) No talk in Senate about lowering bar to end filibusters for legislation. Only discussion about curbing time after Senate has voted to end debate on lower tier nominations before senators take actual confirmation vote
author: ChadPergram

text: 1) Senate GOPers again discussing options for a 3rd “nuclear option” to alter Senate precedent & accelerate the confirmation of some lower tier nominations. The effort is s starting to command headlines. But unlikely to happen unless Senate is appropriate parliamentary posture

text: 4) There is tension between Republican lawmakers and the administration over which specific projects they’ll pilfer for the border wall. Republicans want the wall. But they also don’t want to see their pet projects stripped of cash to pay for it.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) Congress could try to expand OCO (“Overseas Contingency Operations") to cover some money shifted for the wall. OCO is “off-budget & devoted to military-oriented spending. OCO is real money & adds to the deficit. But it's not formally on the books.
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) In other words, there's a limit to the size of each appropriations bill. So…even if the President goes in and starts moving around money, Congress just lift the cap & replenish money devoted to the wall.  The money is gone and the cap stands. Unless Congress lifts the caps
author: ChadPergram

text: 1) Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Richard Shelby (R-AL) recently said they would “backfill” the money moved around or the wall. That’s a problem. Congress imposed sequestration spending caps in 2011 on all 12 of the annual spending bills.
author: ChadPergram

text: Here's the problem facing GOP lawmakers on the nat'l emergency declaration. GOPers want the wall. But they don’t want money diverted for the wall from key programs in their districts or states.
author: ChadPergram

text: We know the “pots” of money the admin intends to raid to get $ for the border wall. But we don’t know the specific programs. Each of these programs CapHill backers. GOP lawmakers will fight if money is shifted from their policy priorities.
author: ChadPergram

text: On border wall national emergency declaration: Fox is told one senior Republican told his GOP colleagues that they just have to make sure the President gets the wall or they would face the wrath of Mr. Trump.

text: 15) Prior to '16, the last 3 successful overrides came on bills vetoed by Bush43. Hse/Senate overrode the President’s veto on two versions of the Farm bill in May and June of 2008. The House and Senate then overrode Mr. Bush’s veto of a Medicare expansion plan in July, 2008.
author: ChadPergram

text: 14) The Senate voted 97-1 to override Obama (66 voted were needed). The House voted 348-77 with one lawmaker voting president. 284 yeas were needed for the override.
author: ChadPergram

text: 13) The last successful veto override came in Sept '16. Obama vetoed the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act. The measure allowed families of 9/11 victims to sue those responsible or the attacks, including Saudi Arabia.
author: ChadPergram

text: 12) The vote to override is based on how many lawmakers ACTUALLY TAKE PART IN THE OVERRIDE ATTEMPT, not on how many members voted on the bill when it passed both bodies. So, determining a PRECISE number is impossible until the veto override vote is actually concluded.
author: ChadPergram

text: 11) It’s possible there could not be an attempt to override. The last unsuccessful attempt to override a veto came in January, 2016. President Obama vetoed a Republican effort to repeal and replace Obamacare. The House voted 241-186, well short of the 285 yeas needed to override.
author: ChadPergram

text: 10) We are not expecting a successful override of a prospective veto of the national emergency. The math simply isn’t there.
author: ChadPergram

text: 9) Successful veto overrides are rare. Requires 2/3 vote by both bodies of Congress. 67 votes in the Senate, provided all 100 sens cast ballots. 427 Hse mbrs  cast ballots on the bill to block nat'l emergency last week. So the yardstick there is 285 yeas. 245 members voted yea
author: ChadPergram

text: 8) President Obama vetoed his first piece of legislation after only 11 months on the job. President George W. Bush never vetoed a bill until he was in office for five-and-a-half years. President Bill Clinton didn’t use a veto until two-and-a-half years into his presidency.
author: ChadPergram

text: 7) If the Senate approves the package, the House and Senate are in alignment and the package goes to President Trump. This likely begs Mr. Trump’s first use of a veto.
author: ChadPergram

text: 6) A vote to overturn the resolution is yet another example of Senate GOP dissension when it comes to Trump. GOP senators have broken w/Trump on Saudi Arabia, cancellation of some Russian sanctions & speedy withdrawal from Syria. Were close to breaking w/Trump on shutdown
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) Fox is told to keep an eye on March 14 for the Senate to handle bill to overturn national emergency in the Senate. Fox is also told the Senate would likely work out an arrangement to handle the issue in one day. The statute provides for up to three days of debate in the Senate
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) Also keep an eye on Sens. Lamar Alexander (R-TN), Mitt Romney (R-UT), Cory Gardner (R-CO) and perhaps Mike Lee (R-UT). Others could be in play as well. Pay particular attention to appropriators.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) Paul becomes the fourth Republican senator to support the effort to reject the national emergency. Others are Sens. Susan Collins (R-ME), Thom Tillis (R-NC) and Lisa Murkowski (R-AK). The first two face competitive re-election bids next year.
author: ChadPergram

text: 2) The Senate math is currently 53 Republicans and 47 senators who caucus with the Democrats. All 47 Democrats are expected to vote in favor of the resolution, including Sen. Joe Manchin (D-WV).
author: ChadPergram

text:
1) Decision by GOP KY Sen Paul to vote in favor of blocking Trump’s national emergency declaration for the border sets two things in motion: 

A) All but guarantees passage of the resolution overturning the declaration in the Senate. 
B) Tees up President Trump’s 1st veto effort
author: ChadPergram

text:
Decision by GOP KY Sen Paul to vote to block Trump’s national emergency tees up likely 1st Trump veto. Takes 2/3 vote of both bodies to override. 67 in Senate. 285 in Hse based on 427 who voted last wk. Hse was 40
votes shy of necessary votes to override
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP KY Sen Rand Paul becomes fourth Republican senator to oppose Trump’s national emergeny for the border wall. He joins GOP Sens Collins, Tillis & Murkowski in planning to vote to block it. Virtually assures passage as all 47 Dems are expected to vote aye
author: ChadPergram

author: ChadPergram

text: How Republicans are making things tough for House Democrats
author: ChadPergram

text: 16) Hse GOPers would revolt if Dems revoked the MTR, curbing what little power the minority has in the Hse Yet ironically, many House Republicans want to curb the power of the minority in the Senate (where Republicans hold the majority) and eliminate the filibuster.
author: ChadPergram

text:
15) “A yes vote is to give leverage to the other side,” said Pelosi. “To surrender leverage on the floor of the House.”

McCarthy suggests that changing the MTR rule would be a “nuclear option.”

“It would leave a stain on this majority,” said McCarthy,
author: ChadPergram

text: 14) Pelosi insists that Democrats should oppose motions to recommit as a matter of policy. Other Democrats believe leaders should give vulnerable Democrats more latitude. There is some chatter that Democrats could try to change the MTR rule.
author: ChadPergram

text: 13) GOP prevailed a few weeks ago, tacking on provisions via a MTR condemning anti-Semitism to a measure designed to halt US action in Yemen. This wk, a GOP MTR added language requiring ICE be told about undocumented persons purchasing weapons to a background check bill.
author: ChadPergram

text: 12) Dems lost Hse in '10 midterms. In the minority, Dems  were never quite as wily with their MTR’s at the GOP. But MTR’s are again an issue since GOPers are back in the minority. We’re not two months into the new Congress and the GOP has already prevailed on two MTR’s on the flr
author: ChadPergram

text: 11) In the succeeding months, GOPers successfully deployed MTR’s against majority Democrats on the so-called “cash for caulkers” bill. The legislation would help people weatherize their homes and install energy efficient windows. Another GOP MTR gutted a science measure.
author: ChadPergram

text: 10) Mindful that their lawmakers could face exposure to these ads, the Democratic leadership yanked the District of Columbia bill off the House floor. The bill to increase the size of the House and grant a vote to Washington, DC never went to a vote – despite debate on the floor.
author: ChadPergram

text: 9) By writing a controversial motion to recommit, GOPers generated a tally where they could document where certain Dems from vulnerable districts might vote against the right to bear arms. Republicans would then prep election ads to portray those Democrats as opposing 2nd Amdt
author: ChadPergram

text: 8) If those gun-friendly Democrats voted with the Republicans, the MTR blew up the Washington, DC bill. If Republicans were successful in goading those same Democrats into voting with the leadership, watch out come election time.
author: ChadPergram

text: 7) The MTR made many conservative, pro-Second Amendment Democrats jumpy. In that instance, those Democrats had to choose to vote with the Republicans and the firearms proposal or against the philosophies of their districts and side with leadership.
author: ChadPergram

text: 6) The best example came in March, 2007. Lawmakers debated a measure to award the District of Columbia a seat in the House. Republicans concocted a motion to recommit which would repeal Washington, DC’s ban on handguns. The MTR was germane because the bill dealt with DC
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) But seeing an opportunity, GOPers began crafting artful MTR’s, crafted in a way to put the squeeze on vulnerable Dems. Dems took pains to protect new mbrs & leaders granted them leeway to vote against MTR's. This created havoc for Dems even though they were in the majority.
author: ChadPergram

text: 4) Most MTR’s resulted in party-line votes until 2007. That’s when Democrats again won control of the House after 12 years in the wilderness. Democrats captured the House with victories by moderate Democrats in battleground districts in the 2006 midterm elections.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) At the end of most Hse debates, just before final passage, the majority provides the minority a parliamentary option, which, depending on how it’s drafted, could either change or possibly kill bills. In its purist form, a MTR is just that: an effort to “recommit” bills to cmte
author: ChadPergram

text:
2) The parliamentary gambit is called the “Motion to Recommit,” or MTR as it’s known in Congressional shorthand. MTR’s must be “germane” and tied directly to the legislation at hand. 

In short, the bill can’t deal with dogs and the MTR focus on cats.
author: ChadPergram

text: 1) GOP creating mischief for Hse Dems using a standard, garden-variety procedural tool to goad Democrats into taking challenging votes on the floor – or risk either defeating or altering legislation which is on the verge of passing.
author: ChadPergram

text: Schiff after closed door Cohen hrng. Says Cohen was "cooperative." Noted that this has been "excruciating" for Cohen. Says "none of the questions we had for him went unanswered."
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen as he leaves the Hse Intel Cmte after closed door session: I am committed to telling the truth. I will be back in March 6 to finish up. There is more to discuss. Thank you guys so much. Sorry you had to wait all day.

text: Cohen completes his third day of testimony on Capitol Hill. Today was a closed door meeting with the House Intelligence Committee

text: GOP FL Sen Scott on if Trump's border emergency could wind up costing FL military money: I don’t want Florida to lose any money. Where is that money going to come from?..I’m on Armed Services and I’m going to make sure that our military bases fulfill duty to the country.

text: From colleague Caroline McKee. GOP FL Sen Scott on GOP Rep Gaetz tweet about Cohen: It is embarrassing and we shouldn’t be doing that stuff up here. You shouldn’t be trying to intimidate them. It’s wrong and disgusting and I’m glad he apologized.

text: GOP TN Sen Alexander on flr. Says he located money Trump could use for border wall w/o emergency. Is worried about separation of pwr. "The next president can declare a nat'l emergency & tear the wall down…there's no limit to imagination to what next left-wing president could do"

Democrats want to rig the rules..Changes to the rules would be the nuclear option..It would leave a stain on this majority just two months in

text: Grijalva on GOP adjourning climate change hrng: They can do it within the rules. They can break the protocol..That's fine..they think they got away with something. Well... we got a long two years ahead of us..hey can go ahead and do that but we are ready for it.

text: House Natural Resources Cmte Chair Grijalva calls move by Gohmert to adjourn climate change hearing a "cheap trick." Adds there are "consequences to breaking these protocols." But GOP had more votes than Dems. So they vote went against Dems

text: Grijalva on GOP adjourning climate hearing because Dems lacked the votes: "When we were in the minority, we never moved to close a meeting. Even if we did not agree with the testimony that was being given. And they did not agree with the testimony and they did not want to hear it
author: ChadPergram

text: Natural Resources Cmte Chair Grijalva says GOP broke "protocol and civility" by moving to adjourn climate hrng when GOPers outnumbered Dems. Calls it "a gotcha trick..a cheap trick. And we will prepared be for it..everybody will be there."

text: Schiff: President Trump’s decision to walk away from the summit w/NKorea without an agreement was preferable to making a bad deal.  It was also the inevitable result of the President’s misplaced faith in his personal relationship with the North Korean dictator, Kim Jong Un

text: GOP OH Sen Portman: I think you just have to be cognizant of the nature of this regime in terms of North Korea and not be naive about what their actions have been.the mistreatment of Otto Warmbier was..unforgivable..that needs to be part of the agenda.
author: ChadPergram

text: From colleague Jason Donner. GOP OH Sen Portman on fmr constituent Otto Warmbier & Trump not discussing Warmbier w/Kim: We shouldn't be naive about this regime and about the way they mistreat their own people. And certainly the way they mistreated Otto Warmbier.

Amateur hour with nuclear weapons at stake...The type of TV drama isn't ultimately make for good diplomacy..we've given up a lot in this process gotten virtually nothing in return. And that's a real concern.

text: Dem OH Sen Brown on Trump not discussing Otto Warmbier w/Kim Jung-un: It sends a message to dictators..that he believes autocrats when they when they lie or when they cover up or when they justify policies that then result in the deaths of innocent human beings
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem OH Sen Brown on NKorea & OH native Otto Warmbier: The president seems to gravitate towards autocrats..you never should go meet with the North Korean dictator without bringing up the name of Otto Warmbier and bring up the whole issue of human rights
author: ChadPergram

text: Graham on Hanoi summit: It’s better to walk away than sign a bad deal..I am encouraged that there are plans to continue talking. We must not go back to the status quo. If negotiations fail, it would be time to end the nuclear threat from North Korea – one way or the other.
author: ChadPergram

text: Blumenthal: I regret that no progress has been made on denuclearizing North Korea. My hope is that we  avoided any damaging concessions secretly in these talks because the president is prone to making these concessions, but I regret that there has been no progress
author: ChadPergram

text: Hirono on Trump & summit: He seems to have a very odd affinity toward dictators..I think there is some kind of psychological thing going on that I don’t want to get into but it’s very odd and I think it’s misplaced.
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem HI Sen Hirono on Trump/NKorea: He went into the meeting thinking that the same kind of flattery that works on him would work on Kim Jong-un and it doesn’t. So I’d say, diplomacy by narcissism doesn’t work and we need to prepare.
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP Sen Rounds on no deal w/NKorea: In the art of the deal you’ll find that you never can want something so badly that you’re willing  to take whatever the other side offers. You still have to have some good common sense and Ronald Reagan used to say “Trust but Verify”
author: ChadPergram

text: From colleague Jason Donner. Sen Mike Rounds (R-SD) on Hanoi summit: I think the president had to decide if whether he could get what he needed or to walk away and part of the art of making the deal is to know when to walk away.
author: ChadPergram

text: McConnell: Kim Jong Un now has a long train ride home, and he will have time to reflect on the future that is still within North Korea’s grasp. But the president has demonstrated that such a future must be accompanied by real de-nuclearization.
author: ChadPergram

text: McConnell: High-level diplomacy can carry high-level risks, but the president is to be commended for walking away when it became clear insufficient progress had been made on de-nuclearization.
author: ChadPergram

text: McConnell: The president has gone the extra mile to demonstrate his sincerity in wanting to resolve this issue. It was smart to bring Kim Jong Un to Singapore and Vietnam, to expose the North Korean delegation to the kind of economic prosperity that could be possible
author: ChadPergram

text: McConnell: The president should be commended for his personal commitment to persuading Kim Jong Un to pursue a different path. By January 2017, it was clear the prior administration’s so-called policy of ‘strategic patience’ had not worked.
author: ChadPergram

text:
Cummings says he spoke to House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-CA) about tomorrow’s Cohen session:
There are a number of things he’s going to be able to use for his hearing from our hearing
author: ChadPergram

text:
Cummings:
I would rather have no hearing than a hearing that interfered with Mueller
author: ChadPergram

text:
Cummings after the Cohen hearing:
I think there are still a number of shoes to drop
author: ChadPergram

text:
Cummings on Cohen:
A lightbulb went off in his head and he said I’m going the wrong way…I think he’s remorseful

Cummings on what he told Cohen before testifying:
If you come in here and you lie..and these were my exact words, I will nail you to the cross
author: ChadPergram

text:
Cummings on Cohen:
I thought he brought a lot to the table. He told of the Donald Trump he knows..I believe he told the truth
author: ChadPergram

text:
Cummings after Cohen hearing: 
We have to be effective and efficient in everything we do…and that means we have to have civility
author: ChadPergram

text: Cummings after Cohen hearing: Over the past two years, there hasn’t been accountability..The Constitution says we are about a check on the executive branch. That’s what this was all about
author: ChadPergram

text: Cummings after Cohen hearing: Today was a very important day. I told my staff, 200 years from now, people will be talking about this moment..we have a situation where we have strayed so far away from normal in our country..I think today was at least an opportunity to do that
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen after the hearing. He briefly says he hopes it will help "heal America."
author: ChadPergram

text: Cummings gavels Cohen hearing to a close. Angrily shouts "We have got to get back to normal!"
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen says Trump's behavior is "churlish." Criticizes Trump for government shutdown.
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen says that if Trump loses 2020 election, he doubts there will be a "peaceful transition of power."
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen hearing resuming momentarily before House Oversight Cmte
author: ChadPergram

text: Freshman Dem ME Rep Golden on his no vote for universal background checks: Maine isn’t Chicago, Washington, or New York. For many of my constituents, access to firearms is a necessary part of daily life and we have a tradition of responsible gun ownership.
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse ok'd universal background checks bill 240-190. 8 GOP yeas. Buchanan, Diaz-Balart, Fitzpatrick, Hurd, KingNY, Mast SmithNJ & Upton. 2 Dem noes: Golden & Peterson
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen hearing now to resume at 4:15 pm et
author: ChadPergram

text:
House approves bill to expand background checks for firearms

The vote was 240 to 190
 
8 Republicans voted yea

2 Democrats voted no
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen hearing expected to resume at 4:08 pm et
author: ChadPergram

text: House now voting on bill to expand background checks for firearms
author: ChadPergram

text: Non-voting delegate to Congress from USVI Plaskett on Gaetz: I think at the very least there should be a referral to the Ethics Cmte of witness intimidation or tampering under USC 1512 of my colleague Matt Gaetz and it may be possibly him being referred for criminal prosecution
author: ChadPergram

text: Non-voting delegate to Congress Plaskett to Cohen: I want to apologize for the inappropriate comments and tweets that have been made by other members of this body
author: ChadPergram

text: Trump campaign: Michael Cohen is a felon, a disbarred lawyer, and a convicted perjurer, who lied to both Congress and the Special Counsel in a ‘deliberate and premeditated’ fashion according to the Special Counsel’s Office..Why did they even bother to swear him in this time?
author: ChadPergram

text:
Pelosi on if Cohen hearing helps set up impeachment:
I spent the morning at Howard University. I didn’t see one word of the hearing…I haven’t been briefed..I have more concern about the bad policies of Donald Trump
author: ChadPergram

text: Pelosi says she hasn’t seen “one word” of the Cohen hearing. Hoyer says Dems would have to “wait for the Mueller report” to see if today’s hearing would tee up impeachment
author: ChadPergram

text: Non-voting Del to Hse from USVI Plaskett says it should be up to Dem ldrs to refer Gaetz to Ethics Cmte. Won't do so herself. “This has not gone unnoticed by members. I think it’s chilling.”
author: ChadPergram

text: Just before the hearing recess, Del. Stacey Plaskett (D-VI), the non-voting delegate to Congress from the U.S. Virgin Islands, suggests that Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL) should be referred to the House Ethics Committee for his tweet Cohen & could face criminal jeopary
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen hearing recesses as members got to the floor for vote series on background checks on guns. Cmte probably won't start again for about an hour or more.
author: ChadPergram

text: House flr vote series starting now. Expect Cohen hearing to recess shortly so mbrs can get to the flr to vote. Final vote in series will be on passing expanded background check measure for firearms. Then Cohen hearing will resume
author: ChadPergram

text: Vote series on the Hse flr on background checks for guns should start around 2:30 pm et. 4 votes likely in series. Last one is on on final passage for expanded background checks. Cmte will likely break a few minutes into vote series..& start again 30 minutes from end of last vote
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate Intel Cmte Chair Burr asks if Cohen has “any proof” of allegations about Stone call with Trump. “Notes? Times? Dates? Calendars? Phone logs?" Burr on if he heard anything inconsistent with what Cohen told Intel Cmte Tues: (Burr pauses) "I’m not going to talk about that"
author: ChadPergram

text: Cummings says Cohen hearing will recess for vote series on the House floor and reconvene "30 minutes after the last vote begins." At least 4 votes in the series, one on final passage on Dem bill to expand background checks for firearms
author: ChadPergram

text:
Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), the top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee on if she’s watching the Cohen hearing:
It’s on, but I’m doing other things. I think he has a credibility problem.
author: ChadPergram

text:
Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-SC) on Cohen testimony:
If you’re trying to hide a crime, you probably wouldn’t write a check.
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate votes to break filibuster on nomination of Andrew Wheeler to be EPA Administrator, 52-46
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP ME Sen Collins to oppose Andrew Wheeler for EPA Admin: I believe that Mr. Wheeler, unlike Scott Pruitt, understands the mission of the EPA and acts in accordance with ethical standards; however, the policies he has supported..are not in the best interest of our environment
author: ChadPergram

text: Graham on Cohen hrng: I think it’s poor form to have it while the president is literally talking with Kim Jong un about giving up his nuclear weapons program. If we had done something like this, people in the media business would be pretty outraged for good reason.
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate now voting to end debate on nomination of Andrew Wheeler to become EPA Administrator
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem MA Rep Lynch to Cohen: I don’t think my colleagues on the other side of the aisle are afraid that you are going to lie. I think they are afraid that you are going to tell the truth
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem VA Rep & Oversight Cmte mbr Connolly on Cohen: I think hes a pretty credible witness and I think the Republicans look a little desperate in trying to discredit him
author: ChadPergram

text: House now debating bill to expand background checks for firearms
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen hearing beginning again before House Oversight Committee
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen calls himself a "fool" at Hse Oversight hrng when asked to describe himself by GOP KY Rep James Comer
author: ChadPergram

text: Break in the Oversight Cmte hearing with Cohen
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP FL Rep Gaetz has apologized & deleted his tweet about Michael Cohen. But Gaetz was standing his ground last night
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen on Trump: Since taking office, he has become the worst version of himself.
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen: Being around Mr. Trump was intoxicating..I wound up touting the Trump narrative for over a decade..it monopolized my life
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen: It seems unbelievable I was so mesmerized by Donald Trump..
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP SC Rep Norman on Cohen; "This guy hasn’t been truthful on anything. so were going try for 4 hours try to interview someone who's going to jail.
author: ChadPergram

text: Graham: A new low for House Democrats: holding hearings with Michael Cohen while President Trump negotiates with North Korea about giving up their nuclear arsenal. Democrats’ hatred of Trump is undercutting an important foreign policy effort and is way out of line.
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen says he "regrets" he helped Trump. Says he is "ashamed of my own failings, my weakness and misplaced loyalty." Says he understands some mbrs of cmte will attempt to question his credibility. Says Trump is "a racist, a conman and he is a cheat."
author: ChadPergram

text: Cummings now searing-in Cohen for hearing.
author: ChadPergram

text: Jordan says the Cohen hearing is so Democrats “can start their impeachment process.”
author: ChadPergram

text: Jordan says "the only questions which can be asked are ones which would do damage to the President of the United States."
author: ChadPergram

text: Jordan upbraids Cummings for holding hearing with Cohen. Says that the hearing was orchestrated by Cohen's attorney, Lanny Davis. Says Cummings "stacked the deck against us."
author: ChadPergram

text: At Cohen hearing, Cummings says “the days of this committee protecting the President at all costs are over.”
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen appearing before House Oversight Cmte at this hour
author: ChadPergram

text: Gaetz deletes tweet about Cohen. Says “While it is important 2 create context around the testimony of liars like Michael Cohen, it was NOT my intent to threaten, as some believe I did. I’m deleting the tweet & I should have chosen words that better showed my intent. I’m sorry.”
author: ChadPergram

text: Trump tweet: Michael Cohen was one of many lawyers who represented me (unfortunately)..he was just disbarred by the State Supreme Court for lying & fraud. He did bad things unrelated to Trump. He is lying in order to reduce his prison time. Using Crooked’s lawyer!
author: ChadPergram

text: Trump tweet: I have now spent more time in Vietnam than Da Nang Dick Blumenthal, the third rate Senator from CT (how is CT doing?). His war stories of his heroism in Vietnam were a total fraud - he was never even there. We talked about it today with Vietnamese leaders!
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse hrng today on US trade with China
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse Foreign Affairs Committee hearing today entitled “The Trump Administration’s Foreign Policy: A Mid-Term Assessment”
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse Armed Svcs Cmte hrng today on “Transgender Service in the Military Policy”
author: ChadPergram

text: Expect discussion on tariffs as Ag Sec Sonny Perdue appears before Hse Agriculture Cmte today
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate hrng today on the Budget Control Act & sequestration caps
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate hrng todwy on protecting the electric grid from an electromagnetic pulse or geomagnetic disturbance.
author: ChadPergram

text: House today to debate & vote on expanded background checks measure today
author: ChadPergram

text: Michael Cohen to appear before Hse Oversight Cmte today in public session. Hearing likely to last all day
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP LA Sen Kennedy on discussion GOP senators had with Pence about nat’l emergency: We talked about the constitutional basis we talked about the issue of Madisonian separation of powers. We talked about the factual basis..nd people raised concerns. People affirmed their support
author: ChadPergram

text:
Pergram to Gaetz on his tweet about Cohen: What do you say to fellow members who criticize your tweet crossed a line?  

Gaetz: I get criticism regularly from my colleagues in the Congress
author: ChadPergram

text: Gaetz on his tweet about Cohen: It has nothing to do with the legitimacy or the illegitimacy of anyone’s extra marital affairs. The question is whether or not someone is honest and truthful and whether or not we can believe them
author: ChadPergram

text:
Pergram to Gaetz on Cohen tweet: What would you say to those who said that tweet went too far? That it was threatening—someone described it as mob-like tactics.

Gaetz: There is no effort to threaten Cohen but of course we need to test witnesses.
author: ChadPergram

text:
Pergram to Gaetz on his tweet about Cohen: Do you know something that we don’t know?
Gaetz: Let's watch the hearing tomorrow and determine what we can find out with rigorous questioning—that is what the institution is intended to do.
author: ChadPergram

text: Gaetz on why he sent the controversial tweet about Cohen: My objective is to figure out whether or not he lied to the people closest to him and I think that says a lot about his veracity and his character.
author: ChadPergram

text: After Gaetz tweet about Cohen, Pelosi is urging the Ethics Cmte to watch social media accounts, to see if lawmakers could be preventing cmtes from getting testimony to do proper oversight.
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen atty Lanny Davis on Gaetz tweet about Cohen: I also trust that his constituents will not appreciate that their congressman has set a new low — which in today’s political culture is hard to imagine as possible.
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen atty Lanny Davis on Gaetz: We will not respond to Mr. Gaetz’s despicable lies and personal smears, except to say we trust that his colleagues in the House, both Republicans and Democrats, will repudiate his words and his conduct.
author: ChadPergram

text: Cohen as he leaves Senate Intel Cmte: At this time I really appreciate the opportunity that was given to me to clear the record, and to tell the truth. And I look forward to..and I'm going to let the American people decide exactly who is telling the truth.
author: ChadPergram

text: Gaetz on Hse flr on Couen: This is someone who has tangled such a web of lies that he is not to be believed, and I think it is entirely appropriate for any member of this body to challenge the truthfulness and veracity, and character for the people who have a history of lies
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP FL Rep Gaetz on Hse flr on Cohen: It will be relevant for us to determine..like does he lie to his own family? Does he lie to his financiers? does he lie to his financiers who are members of his family?
author: ChadPergram

text: 13 GOP yeas to overturn Trump nat’l emergency: Amash Fitzpatrick Gallagher HerreraBeutler Hurd JohnsonSD Massie McMorrisRodgers Rooney Sensenbrenner Stefanik Upton Walden
author: ChadPergram

text: Closed door Senate Intel Cmte finishes all day mtg w/Michael Cohen
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hse ok’s measure to overturn Trump’s nat’l emergency. But a successful veto override needs a 2/3 vote by both bodies of Congress.
 
With 427 voting, that means the House needed 285 yeas to have a veto-proof margin on this legislation. So the House fell 40 votes short of that goal
author: ChadPergram

text:
The House has voted to overturn President Trump’s declaration of a national emergency for the border.
 
The vote was 245-182
 
All Democrats voted yea.
 
They were joined by 13 Republicans.
author: ChadPergram

text: Four GOP yeas on the bord to oveturn Trump’s national emergency. Stefanik, Rooney, JohnsonSD & Amash
author: ChadPergram

text: House now voting on bill to overturn national emergency declaration for the border. We should have a result shortly after 6:30 pm et. Watch to see how many GOPers side with Dems. Unlikely the measure will get close to 2/3, needed to override a threatened presidential veto
author: ChadPergram

text: House finished with debate on measure to overturn Trump's national emergency. Vote coming within the hour.
author: ChadPergram

text: Two Senate votes slated now. Confirmation of Eric Miller, to be Judge for the Ninth Circuit. Then vote to end debate on nomination of Michael  Desmond, to be Chief Counsel for the Internal Revenue Service
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP NC Sen Tillis worries how a future president may use nat'l emergencies for their priorities. "Based on all the information I have, the past precedents, I’m likely to support the resolution of disapproval."
author: ChadPergram

text: Trump threatening veto on measure to overturn border emergency declaration. Trump has never used his veto. Obama 1st used his veto 11 months into his presidency. Bush43 took 5.5 yrs to 1st use his veto. Clinton's 1st veto came 2.5 yrs into his presidency
author: ChadPergram

text: Graham: The only thing being manufactured is Democrats arguing there is no crisis at the border.  Why?  They don’t want to recognize Trump as the legitimate president. Democrats’ refusal to acknowledge the problems and crisis at our southern border is pure political hypocrisy.
author: ChadPergram

text: Graham on Pence at Senate GOP lunch today: The Vice President made a compelling case that the border crisis is real and President Trump has both the authority and legal backing to declare a national emergency.
author: ChadPergram

text: Meadows slams Dems on Hse flr. Says they have "new-found Constitutionalists across the aisle" opposing Trump's national emergency for the border. Says Dems just want to attack Trump.
author: ChadPergram

text: House now debating bill to overturn national emergency declaration for the border
author: ChadPergram

text:
Schumer on how many Republicans will vote to terminate national emergency:
We only need one more..we know there will be pressure put upon them..I am hopeful we will have a significant number
author: ChadPergram

text:
Schumer doesn’t directly answer question on if all Democrats will vote present on Green New Deal as they did on Medicare for all in 2017, but slightly tips his hand:
We’re not going to participate in a sham
author: ChadPergram

text:
Schumer on Green New Deal vote:
It’s just a diversion and a sham..what are you going to do about climate change
author: ChadPergram

text: Schumer says Republicans are “worried” about vote to terminate national emergency & says there could be a “significant” number of Republicans who vote yes
author: ChadPergram

text: 1) All 12 spending bills are capped due to sequestration. Appropriators just can't go in and add other money into the bills to make up the difference from money taken from the border wall. But they can dip into OCO, an off-budget account which is not counted against sequestration
author: ChadPergram

text: From colleague Jared Halpern. Apps Cmte Chair Shelby on plans to take money from Military Construction for the wall: I predict there’d be no trouble in the appropriations committee to backfill, make sure there’s no cut, ultimately, to military construction.
author: ChadPergram

text:
Manchin will support terminating the nat’l emergency because it bypasses Congress’s power of the purse. He cited late Senate MajLdr Robert Byrd who was defender of Congressional prerogatives. 
Manchin:
Can you imagine me holding the seat of Robert Byrd opposing it?
author: ChadPergram

text:
Schumer on President Trump declaring national emergency:
The President is defacing the Constitution for his own personal gain..I can understand why McConnell said they had a robust debate. They’re worried about it
author: ChadPergram

text:
McConnell on how the vote to terminate the border national emergency:
I couldn’t handicap the outcome. But we will be voting on it

McConnell on if he believes the national emergency declaration is lawful:
We’re in the process of weighing it..
author: ChadPergram

text:
McConnell on discussion with Vice President Pence on the national emergency declaration:
We had a fulsome discussion..It dominated the entire discussion..My members were extremely interested in the subject
author: ChadPergram

text:
McConnell on resolution to terminate the national emergency:
It’s privileged. It will come up

McConnell on resolution to terminate the national emergency:
It will come up before the next recess period
author: ChadPergram

text: McConnell promises vote on measure to terminate national emergency in the coming weeks. Says he won’t “handicap” the outcome of the vote
author: ChadPergram

text:
Sen. Joni Ernst (R-IA) on efforts to get a trade deal with China:
Talking with my soybean producers, it does keep them up late at night
author: ChadPergram

text:
McConnell on Green New Deal:
Our friends on the other side seem to be reluctant to vote on a Green New Deal..ifthis is such a popular thing to do, why would anyone want to dodge the vote?..It’s a debate we’ll likely have sometime before the August break
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem Caucus Chair Jeffries on Trump’s bordernnat’l emergency: The president is behaving like a king which is inconsistent with what the founding fathers had in mind. The resolution of disapproval with respect to the president's fake crisis is what we're focused on right now
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse Sem Caucus Chair Jeffries on Trump’s nat’l emergency declaration: President Trump has more stories than Harry Potter and they’re all make believe.
author: ChadPergram

text: WH issues prospective veto threat on measure to overturn national emergency. Trump has not yet vetoed a bill in his presidency
author: ChadPergram

text: Schumer: If the Trump Administration moves forward with this fake climate panel, we will be introducing legislation to defund it..It is long past time for President Trump and Republican leaders to admit that climate change is real
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse Natural Resources Cmte Chair Grijlalva on if he plans to bring fmr Interior Sec Zinke: That's the plan but there's a complication now. The complication being the grand jury, which is beyond the reach of what we're trying to do.
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem TX Rep Castro  on measure to terminate border nat'l emergency: The President is probably going to veto this bill and it's an uphill climb for any veto not just this one. We're challenging him.
author: ChadPergram

text: A discussion on efforts to make permanent a fund to cover the health care costs of 9/11 first responders
author: ChadPergram

text: Fox confirms that GOP AK Sen Murkowski will support a resolution to terminate Trump’s nat'l emergency for the border. This virtually assures that the measure will pass the Senate if/when it comes up if Dems stick together …after it passes the Hse later today (which is expected)
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem RI Rep Cicilline & Dem TX Rep Doggett introduce bill to require Mueller probe final report be made available to the public
author: ChadPergram

text: All Hse Oversight Cmte Dems & GOPers Roy & Amash vote to authorize subpoenas on admin's family separation policy. Cummings: When our own government rips vulnerable children..from the arms of their mothers & fathers with no plan to reunite them, that is gov't-sponsored child abuse
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem Rep Garamendi/GOP Rep Lamborn to Acting DefSec Shanahan: We fear that reprogramming funding intended for military construction projects and counterdrug activities will come at the expense of troop readiness and Dept-wide efforts to address the military's aging infrastructure
author: ChadPergram

text: Wyden to pharmaceutical company CEO's: "The number one reason consumers are getting hammered is because list prices you have set...you have the last word with respect to where they are...all this other stuff is window dressing."
author: ChadPergram

text: Dem Reps. Ro Khanna, Barbara Lee and Andy Kim intro resolution to formally end Korean War
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on background check bill:
The carnage we have seen perpetrated over the past decade has increased over the past decade..Republicans refused to put any legislation on the floor
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on if Cohen is credible:
(Laughs)..I think we should all have questions about his credibility...obviously if he lies to Congress he will face substantially more time..I think that makes him much more likely he will tell the truth
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on the need to soon raise the debt limit:
I’m for doing the debt limit without a deal
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on re-vote in North Carolina’s 9th Congressional district:
I think they should run the re-election wth the same candidates
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on fraud in North Carolina’s 9th Congressional district & a new election coming:
The GOP talks about fraud all the time. Maybe they ought to be looking in their own eye, as the Bible tells us..here there is no doubt there was fraud
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on debt ceiling extension:
I believe the debt limit is a phony issue..I would be for getting rid of the debt limit
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on vote to end national emergency:
I would bet the Senate passes it
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on vote to end national emergency:
I think it is Congress’s responsibility to raise and spend money..the President in a direct response said I’m going to spend it anyway..

Hoyer on vote to end national emergency:
This is a vote of principle
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on measure to overcome national emergency:
I would hope we would get substantial Republican support. If they vote their conscience and for the Constitution, we will
author: ChadPergram

text:
Hoyer on measure to overcome national emergency:
This vote today is about conscience and the Constitution

Hoyer on measure to overcome national emergency:
There is no crisis at the border. However, there is a crisis defending our Constitution
author: ChadPergram

text: Cornyn on resolution to overturn Trump’s border emergency: I intend to vote against the resolution of disapproval.
author: ChadPergram

text: McCarthy on Trump & border emergency: The President did everything he could to work with the House and Senate...at the end of the day the president has a responsibility to making sure people are protected
author: ChadPergram

text: Scalise on measure to overturn Trump’s national emergency: Ultimately we are going to stand with president to make sure we can secure border
author: ChadPergram

text: House Oversight panel authorizes subpoenas of DHS, DOJ officials over family separation policy
author: ChadPergram

text: From colleague Jason Donner. Senate Intel Cmte chair Burr when asked what’s the most important thing you can hear today from Michae Cohen: Burr: “Truth”
author: ChadPergram

text: WH’s Sanders: Disgraced felon Michael Cohen is going to prison for lying to Congress and making other false statements. Sadly, he will go before Congress this week and we can expect more of the same.  It’s laughable that anyone would take a convicted liar like Cohen at his word
author: ChadPergram

text: Fmr Trump atty Michael Cohen arrives for closed door session with Senate Intel Cmte. First of 3 appearances on CapHill this wk for Cohen
author: ChadPergram

text: The House will first debate the “rule” which establishes the parameters of debate on the effort to undo the border nat’l emergency. The actual debate on the bill itself won’t unfold until late afternoon.
author: ChadPergram

text: The House will likely command the support of most if not all Democrats to approve the plan. House Republicans are now working to minimize GOP yeas on the matter.
author: ChadPergram

text: The measure to overturn Trump’s nat’l emergency is subject to a veto. It is not believed there is a two-thirds vote in either chamber to overcome a prospective presidential veto.
author: ChadPergram

text: The Senate will not consider the  measure to overturn the nat’l emergency until at least next month at the earliest. Some observers note the law is so tangled that McConnell may not even have to bring it up. Or, he could face pressure from GOPers to bring the plan up regardless
author: ChadPergram

text: It takes a simple majority for adoption in the House and Senate to oveturn the national emergency. But the President must sign the measure. Although there is a clear majority for passage of the plan in the House, the Senate vote appears to be on the edge.
author: ChadPergram

text: The provision for the House and Senate to vote to undo the national emergency is built into the National Emergencies Act of 1976 which the President used to go around Congress to secure funding for his border wall.
author: ChadPergram

text: The House will debate and vote today on a measure to overturn President Trump’s declaration of a national emergency on the border later today. Needs a simple majority for passage. GOP ldrs trying to contain GOP defections.
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate hrng today with pharmacy company CEO’s on drug pricing
author: ChadPergram

text: Fed Chair Jerome Powell delivers testimony on monetary policy today to Senate Banking Cmte
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse to debate/vote this afternoon on measure to overturn Trump national emergency on the border
author: ChadPergram

text: Michael Cohen to appear behind closed doors today before the Senate Intel Cmte
author: ChadPergram

text: Trump tweet:...This will be remembered as one of the most shocking votes in the history of Congress. If there is one thing we should all agree on, it’s protecting the lives of innocent babies.
author: ChadPergram

text: Trump tweet: Senate Democrats just voted against legislation to prevent the killing of newborn infant children. The Democrat position on abortion is now so extreme that they don’t mind executing babies AFTER birth....
author: ChadPergram

text: Gillibrand on push to permanently fund pgm to help 9/11 1st responders suffering from rare cancers: “The 9/11 death toll is still growing. 9/11 responders are still suffering..45,000 people are suffering."
author: ChadPergram

text: Pelosi on measure to overturn Trump’s national emergency: The President’s power grab usurps that Constitutional responsibility and fundamentally violates the balance of power envisioned by our founders.
author: ChadPergram

text: GOP LA Sen Kennedy on Cohen: Indon't know how you separate fact fact from fiction with Mr. Cohen..he's obviously a very bitter man and he's obviously angry.
author: ChadPergram

text: Three Dem yeas on effort to end filibuster to start debare on late-term abortion bill: Casey, Jones and Manchin were the Dem yeas. Zero GOP nays. Absences were Cramer, Murkowski & Scott (SC)
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate fails to break filibuster to start debate on measure to ban late-term abortions. Vote was 53-44. But needed 60 yeas
author: ChadPergram

text: Clyburn on Dem bill to overturn national emergency: This president must be checked by this Congress...
author: ChadPergram

text: From colleague Jason Donner. Intel Cmte chair Burr on Cohen appearance Tues: When I see..him out with several guys on Sat night in NY, I don’t think he’s hurting too bad..to testify..they should have been worried about obstruction of a Congressional investigation charge
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate now taking procedural vote on effort to start debate on bill barring late-term abortions. Needs 60 yeas
author: ChadPergram

text: House Rules Cmte now mtg to prep measure to overturn Trump’s national emergency for the border & also expanded background check bill for flr action later this wk
author: ChadPergram

text: House to swear-in its new Clerk, Cheryl Johnson this evening
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate Foreign Relations Cmte chair Risch schedules classified briefing this wk on Magnitsky sanctions after the death of Khashoggi & briefing on Yemen
author: ChadPergram

text: Senate to hold procedural vote today to proceed to the “Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act.” Needs 60 yeas.
author: ChadPergram

text: As Senate comes back to session today, GOP NE Sen Deb Fischer delivers George Washington’s Farewell address on the flr. An annual Senate tradition since the 1890s
author: ChadPergram

text: Hse/Senate back today after week-plus recess. Hse Rules Cmte preps measure to overturn national emergency for border & background check bill for action later this week
author: ChadPergram

text:
8) McConnell noted yesterday he was on board with President Trump declaring a national emergency. McConnell on Tuesday:

“He ought to feel free to use whatever tools he wants to use to secure the border. I would not be troubled by that,” replied McConnell.
author: ChadPergram

text: 7) On resolution to terminate Trump's wall national emergency...As one source said to Fox, “If (Senate Majority Leader) Mitch McConnell (R-KY) doesn’t want the resolution to come up, it won’t block it.”
author: ChadPergram

text: 6) Hse would likely seek action with a measure to revoke the national emergency as it pertains to the wall. It can be thornier in the Senate. There is imprecise language in the statute as to how the Senate may consider the legislation
author: ChadPergram

text: 5) Congress can terminate declarations of national emergencies with adoption of a joint resolution. It needs a simple majority & presidential signature. If the President vetoes the resolution, Hse/Senate can move to override the veto, needing the standard two-thirds vote.
author: ChadPergram

text:
4) From a parliamentary perspective, Fox is told that the National Emergencies Act is a legislative mess. It lacks focus and specificity and is inherently vague. 

“It is not the gold standard for writing legislation,” confided one source.
author: ChadPergram

text: 3) Congress approved the National Emergencies Act of 1976, granting presidents latitude to act on any number of priorities he may deem an emergency. Presidents have declared 58 national emergencies since 1976. Thirty-one are renewed each year.
author: ChadPergram

text:
2) On national emergency Hamilton demanded an active executive to curb legislative overreaches and to pose as a bulwark against Congress.

Woodrow Wilson first declared a “national emergency” in 1917 because of an “insufficiency of maritime tonnage” to carry U.S commodities
author: ChadPergram

text:
1) On national emergency:

There is always a healthy tension between the legislative branch and the executive branch. However, it is notable that none other than Alexander Hamilton called for what he characterized as “energy” in the executive when writing in Federalist #70.
author: ChadPergram

text: McConnell: I urge my Democratic colleagues to quickly get serious, put partisanship aside, and work with the president and our homeland security experts to provide the funding needed to secure our borders as we begin the next round of appropriations.
author: ChadPergram

text: McConnell: President Trump’s decision to announce emergency action is the predictable and understandable consequence of Democrats’ decision to put partisan obstruction ahead of the national interest.
author: ChadPergram

text: Colleague John Roberts rpts moving drug interdiction money around for the wall is described by sources as "easy money." However, tapping into MilCon/VA bill is tougher. Mbrs of Congress will complain because it takes away military construction projects in their states/districts
author: ChadPergram

text: A couple of notes on Trump's gambit to transfer money. The Treasury asset forfeiture is easier because it has existing transfer authority. Some of this will hinge on potential restrictions built into reprogramming language.
author: ChadPergram

text: Lowey: The national emergency declaration will rob critical military construction projects of funding, threatening national security to prop up a political vanity project.
author: ChadPergram

text: Apps Cmte Chair Lowey: President Trump’s phony national emergency willfully ignores Congress’ refusal to fund his wasteful border wall, upends democratic norms, and creates a disturbing precedent.

text: Pelosi/Schumer: We call upon our Republican colleagues to join us to defend the Constitution. Just as both parties honored our oath to protect the American people by passing the conference committee bill, the Congress on a bipartisan basis must honor the Constitution
author: ChadPergram

text: Pelosi/Schumer: The President's actions clearly violate the Congress’s exclusive power of the purse, which our Founders enshrined in the Constitution.  The Congress will defend our constitutional authorities in the Congress, in the Courts

text: Pelosi/Schumer: The President’s unlawful declaration over a crisis that does not exist does great violence to our Constitution and makes America less safe, stealing from urgently needed defense funds for the security of our military and our nation.  This is plainly a power grab

text: Under the admin’s proposal to shift $8b for the wall...they are moving money BETWEEN appropriations bills. It’s one thing to do so INSIDE an appropriations silo. It’s another to move money between them. That’s what is being cited as the extra-Constitutional part of the gambit
author: ChadPergram

text:
From colleague Blake Burman. The extra $8 billion Trump wants to move around for the eall. $1.375B from the DHS appropriations bill
$601M from Treasury drug forfeiture fund
$2.5B from the Defense’s drug interdiction program 
$3.5B from the military construction bill

text: Lawmakers from both parties aren't entirely pleased w/spending bill to avoid a shutdown. But, the fact that the sides forged a bipartisan compromise in the face of adversity bodes well for future legislation. Had the bill gone south, that could have set the tone for this Congress

text: NRCC Chair Emmer: The stakes in 2020 could not be higher, and we are going to fight like hell until the last poll closes on Election Day to hold the socialist Democrats accountable for their extremism.
author: ChadPergram

text: NRCC chair Emmer: We could have gotten a much better deal if Democrats weren’t so blinded by their quest for open borders and their hatred of ICE that they were willing to jeopardize the safety of our law enforcement personnel on the southern border.
